mdRecord.dcterms:description: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site in southeastern Berks County, near Elverson, Pennsylvania, is an example of an American 19th century rural "iron plantation". For charcoal to burn properly, it was important to keep it dry. Charcoal was hauled by teamsters into this shed and dumped by pulling out the bottom boards of the wagons. After the charcoal had a chance to cool down completely, it was shoveled through the big windows into the charcoal house. When the house was filled to the roof, there was enough charcoal to fuel the furnace for six months. Hopewell Furnace was founded in 1771 by ironmaster Mark Bird. http://www.nps.gov/hofu/forteachers/upload/sgtour.pdf [work]
